Cel Shading in Modern OpenGL — A Tribute to Zelda
Exploring how to recreate Breath of the Wild’s distinctive cel-shaded shadows using modern OpenGL techniques. A dive into stylized lighting and shadow mapping to capture that iconic Zelda look.

## Introduction

The art style of The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild has captivated players worldwide with its vibrant colors, painterly landscapes, and distinctive cel-shaded look. One of the key visual elements that help define its unique aesthetic is the stylized shadows—sharp, expressive, and carefully crafted to enhance the game’s atmosphere without aiming for photorealism.

In this post, we explore how modern OpenGL techniques can be used to recreate these iconic cel-shaded shadows. By combining traditional shadow mapping with toon-style lighting, we can capture that blend of realism and artistry that makes Zelda’s world so enchanting. Whether you’re a graphics developer or an enthusiast, diving into stylized shadows is a great way to deepen your understanding of both lighting and non-photorealistic rendering in real-time 3D graphics.
